com.google.mu.util.stream

Class BiStream<K,V>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.google.mu.util.stream.BiStream<K,V>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AutoCloseable

    public final class BiStream<K,V>
extends Object
implements AutoCloseable
    A Stream-like object making it easier to handle pairs of objects.

    Throughout this class, "key-value" metaphor is adopted for method names and type names. This naming convention however does not imply uniqueness in terms of type <K> nor does it require Object.equals(java.lang.Object) (except for distinct()). Technically a key-value pair is nothing but two arbitrary objects.

    This "key-value" metaphor doesn't always make sense in the problem domain. For example, you may be looking at a pair of doctor and patient; neither is a "key" therefore using methods like filterKeys() may introduce noise to the code. It may improve readability in such cases to avoid these *Keys(), *Values() convenience methods and prefer the pair-wise methods. Like, instead of doctorsAndPatients.filterKeys(Doctor::isInNetwork), consider to use doctorsAndPatients.filter((doctor, patient) -> doctor.isInNetwork()).

    Keys and values are allowed to be null.

    Since:
    1.1

      • biStream

        public static <T> BiStream<T,T> biStream(java.util.stream.Stream<? extends T> stream)
        Wraps stream as a BiStream. Users will typically chain mapKeys() or mapValues(). For example: 
        
 BiStream<UserId, Profile> profilesByUserId = biStream(users.stream())
     .mapKeys(User::getId)
     .mapValues(User::getProfile);
        Alternatively: 
        
 BiStream<UserId, Profile> profilesByUserId =
     biStream(users.stream(), User::getId, User::getProfile);

      • biStream

        public static <T,K,V> BiStream<K,V> biStream(java.util.stream.Stream<? extends T> stream,
                                             java.util.function.Function<? super T,? extends K> toKey,
                                             java.util.function.Function<? super T,? extends V> toValue)
        Wraps stream as a BiStream with keys and values computed using toKey and toValue.
        Since:
        1.11

      • zip

        public static <K,V> BiStream<K,V> zip(java.util.stream.Stream<? extends K> keys,
                                      java.util.stream.Stream<? extends V> values)
        Zips up keys and values into a BiStream in order. If one streams is longer than the other, the extra elements in the longer stream are silently ignored.

        For example: 

        
 BiStream.zip(Stream.of("a", "b", "c"), Stream.of(1, 2))
     .map((x, y) -> x + ":" + y)
        will return a stream equivalent to Stream.of("a:1", "b:2").

      • neighbors

        public static <T> BiStream<T,T> neighbors(java.util.stream.Stream<? extends T> elements)
        Returns a sequential BiStream with every neighboring pairs in elements streamed in the same order as elements. For example neighbors([1, 2, 3, 4]) will return [{1, 2}, {2, 3}, {3, 4}].

        Empty stream is returned if {@code elements} is empty or contains a single element.

        Since:
        1.10

      • indexed

        public static <V> BiStream<Integer,V> indexed(java.util.stream.Stream<? extends V> values)
        Returns a BiStream where each element in values is keyed by its corresponding 0-based index. For example, the following code transforms a list of inputs into a pre-sized output list: 
        
 List<T> output = ...;
 BiStream.indexed(inputs.stream())
     .mapValues(this::convertInput)
     .forEach(output::set);

        Because Java runtime typically caches Integer instances for the range of [0, 128], auto-boxing cost is negligible for small streams.

      • toMap

        public Map<K,V> toMap()

        Equivalent to collect(Collectors::toMap).

        1.2

      • toConcurrentMap

        public ConcurrentMap<K,V> toConcurrentMap()

        1.2

        @Deprecated
public BiCollection<K,V> toBiCollection(CollectorStrategy collectorStrategy)
